item.title: U.S. oil and gas emissions of ozone-forming chemical may be higher than EPA estimates
item.description: Besides greenhouse gasses, U.S. oil and natural gas production emits ethane. A new study indicates that ethane emission levels are about three times higher than the EPA’s estimates.

item.title: Monsoon simulations demonstrate impact of rain-induced cooling on weather patterns
item.description: Raindrops that are cooler than the ground they land on have a cooling effect, one often omitted from weather models. A new study finds that this effect in India can reduce overall rainfall.

item.title: Voyage of collaboration
item.description: The Ship Of Opportunity Program is an international effort that supports the implementation of a network of cargo vessels, cruise ships, and research vessels to deploy scientific instruments that…

item.title: Combined ocean-atmosphere data improves complex ocean forecasts
item.description: A new study finds that combining data from both the ocean and atmosphere can lead to more accurate forecasts, even in complex environments like the Red Sea.

item.title: Understanding the complexities of Tribal communities in rural Alaska
item.description: New resources can help researchers, academics, and federal and state agencies working in rural Alaska understand the current landscape and complexities of Tribal communities.

item.title: Half a century of insight: The International Tree-Ring Data Bank’s vital role in climate research
item.description: The International Tree-Ring Data Bank is a vital scientific resource containing over 6,000 tree ring chronologies used to study long-term climate patterns and environmental changes.

item.title: Wildfire smoke impacted air quality across the United States from 2018 to 2023
item.description: A new study finds wildfire smoke significantly raised fine particulate matter and ozone levels, leading to numerous days when air pollution exceeded health standards.

item.title: Unintended warming: How reduced ship emissions may accelerate climate change
item.description: New international shipping regulations have drastically cut sulfur emissions from ships. While crucial for improving air quality and public health, reducing ship tracks also reduces their cooling…

item.title: Anthropogenic effects on tropical cyclones near Western Europe
item.description: A new study finds the observed increase in tropical cyclone frequency near Western Europe from 1966 to 2020 is likely linked to the anthropogenic aerosol effect.

item.title: Super-marine heatwaves: A new term for a growing concern
item.description: 2023 was a record-breaking year. According to the Annual 2023 Global Climate Report, 2023 was the warmest year since global atmospheric temperature records began in 1850, at 1.18°C (2.12°F) above the…
